Despite its small footprint, it delivers solid performance with quick charging and pass-through capabilities, and it even supports trickle charging for smaller devices like smartwatches or earbuds. What makes the NB10000 Gen 3 stand out is its power-to-weight efficiency. In independent tests, it delivered more usable energy per ounce than any other power bank in its class. The carbon fiber frame and new rubber-corner design give it better drop protection and durability, while the IPX5 water resistance rating means it can handle light rain or spills with ease. Whether you need a fast-charging solution for hikes, flights, or daily commuting, the Nitecore NB10000 Gen 3 delivers serious power without the bulk. Yes, you can bring a power bank on a plane, but only in your carry-on baggage. Power banks are classified as lithium battery devices, and aviation regulations prohibit them from being stored in checked luggage due to fire risks. This rule applies across most major airlines globally, including the TSA in the United States. Most carriers follow Watt-hour (Wh) limits to determine whether a power bank is allowed: Power banks under 100Wh are permitted in carry-ons with no limit on quantity. Power banks between 100Wh and 160Wh are allowed, but only two per passenger, and youâ€™ll need airline approval. Power banks over 160Wh are completely banned from passenger aircraft. To check your power bankâ€™s watt-hour rating, look for it printed on the label or calculate it using: Wh = (mAh Ã· 1000) Ã— Voltage. However, not all countries follow the same rules. A recent policy shift by the Civil Aviation Administration of China (CAAC) now prohibits passengers from flying with non-certified power banks on domestic flights. As of June 28, 2025, power banks must carry the CCC (China Compulsory Certification) label to be allowed onboard. This change comes in response to a series of overheating incidents and mass recalls from major brands like Anker and Romoss, who were found using defective or unauthorized battery cells in over 1.2 million units. While most power banks under 100Wh are allowed on planes, always double-check local airline policies, especially when traveling in or through countries with stricter regulations like China. And for safetyâ€™s sake, avoid using damaged, off-brand, or uncertified models. Note: this article may contain affiliate links that help support our authors and keep the Phandroid servers running.

Looking for the best power bank in 2025? Whether youâ€™re charging a smartphone, tablet, laptop, or wireless earbuds, todayâ€™s power banks are faster, smarter, and more versatile than ever. With USB-C PD, high-wattage outputs, and even MagSafe compatibility, the right portable charger can keep your devices powered up at home, in transit, or on the go.

Samsung Galaxy S25 Edge Review (SAVE $400!)

In this guide, weâ€™ve handpicked five of the best options across different categories, from high-capacity laptop chargers to slim travel-friendly designs. Whether you need fast charging for your iPhone or a 140W powerhouse for your MacBook, thereâ€™s a power bank here that fits your needs and budget.

Nitecore NB10000 Gen III (Gen 3)

ðŸ¥‡ Editorâ€™s Choice

Capacity: 10,000mAh | Weight: 5.3 oz | Ports: 1x USB-C | Water Resistance: IPX5 | Charging Time: 4 hours

If youâ€™re looking for the best power bank that balances weight, durability, and charging performance, the Nitecore NB10000 Gen 3 is hard to beat. Weighing just 5.3 ounces, itâ€™s one of the lightest and most compact 10,000mAh power banks on the market, making it an ideal companion for backpackers, digital nomads, or anyone who travels light. Despite its small footprint, it delivers solid performance with quick charging and pass-through capabilities, and it even supports trickle charging for smaller devices like smartwatches or earbuds.

What makes the NB10000 Gen 3 stand out is its power-to-weight efficiency. In independent tests, it delivered more usable energy per ounce than any other power bank in its class. The carbon fiber frame and new rubber-corner design give it better drop protection and durability, while the IPX5 water resistance rating means it can handle light rain or spills with ease. Itâ€™s a minimalist device by design, with a single USB-C port and no USB-A, so youâ€™ll need to make sure your cables are compatible.

While the 4-hour recharge time is longer than some budget options, the trade-off is worthwhile if you value efficiency and packability. Itâ€™s a strong contender in the ultralight USB-C power bank category and perfect for those prioritizing weight savings and rugged design. Whether you need a fast-charging solution for hikes, flights, or daily commuting, the Nitecore NB10000 Gen 3 delivers serious power without the bulk.

If youâ€™re hunting for the best power bank with wireless charging, the Anker MagGo is a premium option tailored for iPhone users. With full MagSafe compatibility and a strong magnetic hold, it attaches securely to your phone and delivers 15W wireless charging without needing a cable. A built-in flip-out stand makes it easy to prop your device up while it charges, and a digital display shows battery level and estimated charging time.

Beyond wireless, this portable charger also supports fast USB-C charging at 27W for Android devices and can top up a Pixel or iPhone in just over an hour. For those prioritizing convenience and style, this is one of the best power bank options available in 2025.

Can You Bring a Power Bank on a Plane?

Yes, you can bring a power bank on a plane, but only in your carry-on baggage. Power banks are classified as lithium battery devices, and aviation regulations prohibit them from being stored in checked luggage due to fire risks. This rule applies across most major airlines globally, including the TSA in the United States.

Most carriers follow Watt-hour (Wh) limits to determine whether a power bank is allowed:

  • Power banks under 100Wh are permitted in carry-ons with no limit on quantity.

  • Power banks between 100Wh and 160Wh are allowed, but only two per passenger, and youâ€™ll need airline approval.

  • Power banks over 160Wh are completely banned from passenger aircraft.

To check your power bankâ€™s watt-hour rating, look for it printed on the label or calculate it using:

Wh = (mAh Ã· 1000) Ã— Voltage.

However, not all countries follow the same rules. A recent policy shift by the Civil Aviation Administration of China (CAAC) now prohibits passengers from flying with non-certified power banks on domestic flights. As of June 28, 2025, power banks must carry the CCC (China Compulsory Certification) label to be allowed onboard. This change comes in response to a series of overheating incidents and mass recalls from major brands like Anker and Romoss, who were found using defective or unauthorized battery cells in over 1.2 million units.

While most power banks under 100Wh are allowed on planes, always double-check local airline policies, especially when traveling in or through countries with stricter regulations like China. And for safetyâ€™s sake, avoid using damaged, off-brand, or uncertified models.
